title: Lib Dem MP Heidi Allen stands down saying she is ‘exhausted by the nastiness’
text:
Heidi Allen will not stand for re-election in December (Picture: PA)

Liberal Democrat MP Heidi Allen has said she will not stand in the next General Election, citing the toxic atmosphere over Brexit.

The former Tory politician, who has represented South Cambridgeshire since 2015, added that she is ‘exhausted by the invasion into my privacy and the nastiness and intimidation that has become commonplace’.

She informed her constituents of her decision in a letter, saying it left her feeling ‘heartbroken.’

But she added that Brexit has ‘broken our politics’ and she believed that neither Labour nor the Tories had the national interest at heart by agreeing to another election this year.

She wrote: ‘I have been your representative for four and a half years.

‘During that time, we have had an unprecedented two general elections, a referendum and unbelievably a third general election is now on the near horizon.

‘But more than all of that. I am exhausted by the invasion into my privacy and the nastiness and intimidation that has become commonplace.

‘Nobody in any job should have to put up with threats, aggressive emails, being shouted at in the street, sworn at on social media, nor have to install panic alarms at home.

‘Of course, public scrutiny is to be expected but lines are all too regularly crossed and the effect is utterly dehumanising.

‘In my very first election leaflet I remember writing “I will always be a person first and a politician second” – I want to stay that way.’

Heidi Allen wrote a letter to her constituents in South Cambridgeshire telling them why she would be standing at the forthcoming election

Ms Allen reiterated her stance on the need for a People’s Vote – a position that caused her to split from the Tories and join the Independent Group for Change earlier this year.

On October 9th, she announced she had joined the Lib Dems.

Her colleague Chuka Umunna expressed disappointment at Ms Allen not contesting her seat in December’s vote, saying: ‘Very sad about it. We need more people like Heidi in politics.’

His view was echoed by former colleague Anna Soubry who tweeted: ‘This is hugely sad.

‘We need people like Heidi in Parliament – keeping us all on our toes and championing causes they passionately believe in. Too many good people are set to leave this Parliament & will be replaced with non event yes men and women.’
